Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 10:01PM CandDsMom wrote: My husband took some of me pre BMX.  I have only looked at them a few times post op but am very glad to have them although I don't think anyone else will ever see them.  I also think it will be helpful for eventual nipple recon to have them as well...
Posts.Title: Nude/Topless Photo Shoot Anne068 Oddball1

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 09:38AM CandDsMom wrote: txlouise: I would go with your gut and it sounds like you don't 100% entirely feel comfortable with the "watch and wait" scenario.  Can you get a copy of your mammo report?  Did they tell you to come back in 6 months for a repeat exam?  Since BC can be hard to see even with mammo and ultrasound, I would get a 2nd opinion of your palpable lump with an NCI affiliated breast surgeon.  Here is the NCI center website listing: cancercenters.cancer.gov/cance...  Wishing you well! take care.
Posts.Title: Should I get a second opinion txlouise keepthefaith

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 05:30PM - edited Jul 16, 2010 05:38PM by CandDsMom Hi Scully- Did they give you a BIRADS label on your study?  Were you BIRADS-3 (come back in 6 months for a repeat exam but probably benign?).   I don't want to scare you as I think my situation was actually pretty rare but I had 2 clusters of microcysts as well as some "indeterminant calcifications" that were thought to be benign and due to recent breastfeeding on my annual mammogram this February.  I got the whole "BIRADS-3 come back in 6 months" talk but I self referred to a breast surgeon and insisted on a biopsy which ended up showing DCIS which is noninvasive breast cancer.   I want to stress here that this was a change from my baseline mammogram.  Also my case was a bit different than yours as I have a family history of early breast cancer.  Cysts in the breasts are super common in women of all ages and also I imagine having some surgery to the breast may predispose you to some small cysts just as a part of the healing process.   Perhaps you can visit a breast specialist to have an consultation and figure out next steps if you are concerned about it? take care...
Posts.Title: Microcyst clusters scully CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2010 09:53AM CandDsMom wrote: maggie12 -  Unfortunately my DCIS was in both the 2 microcysts and in the calcifications.  I had an MRI after the initial 2 core biopsies showed grade 2 DCIS in the microcysts and the MRI lit up with an 8x6x7cm area (yes my postpartum post nursing breasts were DD+ HUGE!) in my right upper outer quadrant as well as an additional 1.1cm "surprise" under one of the microcysts.  When they did my final pathology what showed up was numerous small areas of DCIS (biggest 5-6mm) with up to 14mm of normal tissue separating them... My oncologist said ultimately I was probably diagnosed 2-3 years before I would have been had I not pushed for the biopsy.  She said what would have likely happened is that they would have looked again in 6 months, things would have been roughly the same, maybe slightly different but DCIS in general is so slow growing that mine has probably been there for some years already.  Anyway at some point down the line I would have been biopsied and it may well have been worse (like possibly invasive cancer). With regards to the "simple" versus "complex" issue: a complex cyst is one that has septations (little strands of tissue) dividing it into different parts, or it appears to have areas of solid tissue in it as well (versus being liquid filled).  Mine were so small they were just called a "microcyst cluster."  As far as I am aware however you cannot make a definitive diagnosis without sticking a needle in there so things can appear to be radiographically benign but there is a judgement call there. I don't think you are being paranoid although it is most likely that you are fine.  But what is the harm in making sure?  The thing to realize is that there is no one who is as invested in your health as you - I have learned that you have to truly be your own advocate and speak up if something doesn't feel right.  I would personally get a 2nd opinion on everything with a breast surgeon at a National Cancer Institute certified (NCI) Center. http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/cancer-centers-list.html take care and feel free to PM me if you'd like...
Posts.Title: Microcyst clusters scully CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 12:20AM CandDsMom wrote: just wanted to say that I saw your post - so sorry to hear the news - I am sure this has got to be beyond scary right now, but I am glad that there is a plan coming into place.   Herceptin is going to kick your BC's butt!! (((hugs)))
Posts.Title: Got results LuvMyLab JannyM

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 09:36AM CandDsMom wrote: Hi Sanbar - I don't have a BRCA mutation but didn't want to leave your post hanging. You may also want to post in the "BRCA" forum as well. Anyway, my understanding of the three possible results from BRCA 1 and 2 testing is: positive for mutation known to be associated with breast/ovarian cancer in BRCA 1 and/or 2 negative for the above variant of unknown significance "VUS" I think the last category has got to be pretty tough to deal with b/c they see something different about the way your BRCA 1 or 2 (I guess BRCA 2 is what you mentioned?) gene looks BUT they don't know if it is associated with cancer or not.  From what my onc said, Myriad, the lab in Utah that does the testing, is compiling a list of these "VUS" mutations and at some point in the future IF they are able to link more definitively to breast/ovarian CA may be included as a positive BRCA test result. These VUS mutations could also be red herrings and not associated with anything though. So it truly is a shoulder shrugger unfortunately because I don't think anyone knows one way or another.  I do have a friend who has a VUS and her doctor is taking a more conservative approach with her - she is enrolled in an ovarian cancer screening program where she gets bloodwork and pelvic ultrasounds every 6 months (actually I am in it too just due to personal hx of BC at a young age). I am sorry if you are having to deal with this uncertainty too, on top of BC.  It sure isn't fair.  (((hugs)))
Posts.Title: brca2 variant of uncertain significance sanbar8771 Bradygirl

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 07:20PM CandDsMom wrote: Sorry to intrude - re shingles vaccine, it is probably not routinely given pre-chemo because it is a live virus vaccine, thus can actually give you a disseminated (all over body) illness if it is given to someone with a low immune system.   So it is actually contra-indicated in patients with HIV/AIDS, certain immune suppressing medications (like humera/methotrexate/etc for auto-immune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis/lupus/Crohn's disease), or any sort of cancer issue (like CLL/chronic leukemia) or chemotherapy.   I am not sure how long it takes for an immune-competent person to be "out of the danger zone" for the shingles vaccine... For MMR, another live virus vaccine (that can cause serious birth defects if administered during pregnancy) they usually say if someone is considering pregnancy they need to wait 4-6 weeks post the vaccine before becoming pregnant to clear the virus from their bodies so perhaps that is a similar time frame to the zostavax or shingles vaccine to clear from the body. Either way sorry to hear you are having to deal with this Iago - I hope you feel better soon!

Posts.Title: Can't stop worrying :( Mommy2Katelynn Makratz

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 01:44AM CandDsMom wrote: Hi MSV1984, sorry that you have occasion to be thinking about all this stuff too.  I am not BRCA + but my oncologist thinks I have something (I am 5th on my father's side in the last 3 generations and was dx at 35, his sister dx at 28).  So they also recommended that I retest every 3-5 years or so and I got enrolled in the ovarian cancer screening program. And I got a L prophy MX (I had R multifocal multicentric ER/PR - DCIS at 34). But I thought I would pop in to comment Re: recovery after breast reconstruction.  I think that this is very dependent on who does your surgery as well as what kind you get done.  I went with a perforator flap, and I was pretty busty before (DD++) and am overall happy that I did.  I certainly however had some significant complications at the time of my surgery at well known chicago based National Cancer Institute center. If I had it to do over again (and were choosing the flap again, which I certainly would), I would recommend that you do research and pick a top group to start with.  I have had 3 surgeries now, and the pain was very deal-able with each of them (and the urinary catheter was out within a day pretty much before I even noticed it and the IV catheters were not painful at all). And had I started with a better plastic surgeon to begin with I would only have needed 2 surgeries instead of the multiple I am ending up with now.  Check out the following websites and also the FORCE website as others have mentioned about to see what is possible with reconstruction. A prophylactic nipple sparing mastectomy may be an option for you if P BMX is on the table. It is a sucky decision to have to make, but even with my complications the experience, while incredibly emotionally difficult, has been very doable in my opinion.  Best wishes to you.  www.breastcenter.com www.drmarga.com  www.naturalbreastreconstructio...
Posts.Title: BRCA1 + and need advice msv1984 CandDsMom

Posts.Content: CandDsMom wrote: Hi all- I had a BMX with R SNB (3 nodes removed) for intermediate to high grade ER PR neg DCIS multifocal multicentric almost a year ago. My first surgery was botched by my recon guy, so I have had to have 3 additional revision surgeries to my breasts. I have been very careful to avoid BPs and sticks in the R arm but have noticed intermittent heaviness and fullness in the arm since the initial BMX. My BS (and the first PS) absolutely denied the possibility that this could be LE, so I self referred to a LANA PT who said that I had about a 6% change in size in the right arm (parts of it were 4cm larger than the other side) and she said she thought I probably have stage 0 LE and that there may be changes going on at the microscopic level.  Of course she gave me good info regarding prevention (wearing gloves with dishes, etc) and is getting me a referral to get a better sleeve made but of course this weekend when I was making cookies with my little guy I burned my right arm on the cookie stone.  I took advil, have been putting triple abx ointment on it and monitoring closely. My arm is not red, but definitely feels very heavy and full.  It is a small area that is burned (maybe 1cm x 0.5 cm) and doesn't look infected but since my heaviness and fullness symptoms have gotten worse I am looking for advice - should I be doing exercises? If so which kind (she didn't really give me any info re: exercises) or should I just be calling the PT back? Thanks much in advance! intermediate to high grade multifocal multicentric ER/PR negative DCIS. HER-2+ of unclear significance. s/p BMX Log in to post a reply

The arm seems to be settling down and thankfully no sign of infection yet :) The cookies were yummy BTW! thanks much for the advice, and the welcome!
Posts.Title: LE? advice appreciated! CandDsMom CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 02:30PM - edited Apr 26, 2011 02:33PM by CandDsMom Trabby - paternal history is absolutely relevant. Frankly though, even without a family history a lump deserves to be investigated (mammograms miss ~10% of breast cancers).   In my case, all my family history is all on my dad's side - his sister (locally advanced BC at age 28), and 3 of his great aunts (breast for 3 and ovarian CA for one in addition to breast).  Interestingly his mother died in her 90s of a totally unrelated ailment. I was 34 when my mammogram came back very mildly abnormal.  The ultrasound picked up 2 small microcysts 3mm and 7mm. I self referred to a breast surgeon and insisted on a biopsy which everyone assured me would be benign (the radiologist actually told me it would "make my anxiety better" while they were doing it!) and, oops, lo and behold I did have early stage BC.  In both spots.  A subsequent MRI revealed an additional 9x8x5 cm area of more multifocal DCIS!   I am BRCA 1 and 2 negative FYI - my personal opinion is that there are other breast cancer genes out there that just have not been identified.  My GAIL model score for developing breast cancer in 2010 was 0.04%.  Long and the short of it - after reviewing my family history my onc also thought that I probably had some sort of hereditary BC issue. If your doctor won't work with you, find another one who will - preferably at an NCI affiliated center. It is your body and your life, and no one else can or will advocate for you in the same way as you can.  Now, I don't want to freak you out overly much with my story, but I remembered feeling much the way you are describing - when I came home from my diagnostic mammogram I was crying - I knew something was wrong and I couldn't believe they were going to try to make me wait 6 months to see. I'm glad I didn't wait.  You shouldn't have to either.  (((hugs)))

Posts.Title: Paternal breast cancer history Trabby SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2010 04:37AM CandDsMom wrote: Have you tried to put a warm compress on it a few times a day?  Sometimes that helped me when I had a plugged duct.  It may also help with a sebacious cyst.  I echo other posts - you should call your doctor again and tell him/her that you are really stressing about this and that you want the ultrasound done now.  Changes related to lactation (milk of calcium, etc) are seen on ultrasound and mammography up to 6 months after breastfeeding but they should be able to get a pretty good look just with ultrasound at this point. Take some deep breaths -  do you have any close family or friends who you can talk to who know what is going on?  You will get through this!

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 04:43PM CandDsMom wrote: Hi Tanya- The good news is that the statistics are on your side - for someone your age to have BC is pretty unlikely.  It is a lot more likely that it is a fibroadenoma or something like that. BUT, I definitely know about the waiting game. I guess the one thing I would say is that don't take what you read on these threads to be representative of what happens in real life. Most of us are here because we are dealing with/have dealt with an actual breast cancer diagnosis. Had my biopsy last year been benign I would just have been out there living my life and not spending any time here at BCO.  I think that is true of probably most of the women here. I think the statistics say that the vast majority of biopsied lumps are benign. That being said, I will wait along with you.  (((hugs))) and hoping for benign results for you.

I have definitely heard of this grey area type of situation, but you'd sure hate things to be leaning for towards the DCIS side and under-treat.  Just my 2 cents though. Posts.Title: Paternal breast cancer history Trabby SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 12:41AM - edited Feb 18, 2011 12:42AM by CandDsMom I am another one with multifocal/multicentric disease, thus my right breast had to go and there was no option for lumpectomy.  I personally did the BMX because I was scared, had a strong family history, was 35 years old, ER-, had a 2 year old and 9 month old at home, etc but I think it is a highly personal decision to do lumpectomy vs mastectomy.   I will say this, it is hard to truly understand the loss of your breast(s) before they are gone, and I miss mine every day (this is not to say that for me it wasn't the right thing to get a MX, but it is an amputation, and a loss, and no matter how good the reconstruction it will never be what I was born with).   I think you have to go with your gut and what feels right to you, once you have had all the statistics explained to you by your BS or onc (and once all testing, genetic/MRI, etc has been done).  It is a tough choice, and it sucks that any of us have had to make it.  Good luck with your decision - do the right thing for you, and you alone. take care! *edited for spelling
Posts.Title: What were the reasons that you had a MX versus a lumpectomy geogal anneflorida

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 09:09AM CandDsMom wrote: LEMOM- I am sorry to hear about what is going on.  Hopefully this will just be an infection that clears.  I am definitely glad to hear that you have some very proactive doctors on your side though.  I don't think you can ever be too careful when it comes to these types of issues. Re the biopsy: I was able to drive myself home post ultrasound guided core biopsy, but I didn't need to have any pain or other meds before hand.  I think if I had taken something for pain or anxiety I would not have been able to drive.  I noticed some soreness in the spots that went away after a few days.  If you have an excisional biopsy that might be different since the area removed might be bigger.  If you think however that you would be too nervous to drive, or to even get the procedure done, is there anyone who could go with you for moral support? Hoping for this to clear up and for B9 results for you if a biopsy happens.  Take care!

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 10:10PM CandDsMom wrote: Hi Susskins- I would second the above post - I would truly look into nipple sparing mastectomy.  If I could have kept my nipples (even if just on the prophy side) it would have made a huge difference.  I had a flap based reconstruction, and did have some complications due to not choosing an experienced enough microsurgeon to start with (despite all my researching I got someone who did a good job putting up a living flap but no artistry)  so if you are going down that road I strongly recommend choosing a surgical team with lots of experience.  It means travel up front but this would have saved me time and money compared to what I went through with my complications.  Anyway, whatever you do, if you want to see some sites of what is possible with flap based reconstruction here are some sites www.breastcenter.com   www.drmarga.com   www.naturalbreastreconstruction.com  www.diepflap.com take care!
